text: ben bernanke you were arguably the most
exposed individual in the whole world at
the time that the financial and economic
crisis hit were you aware of the burden
of responsibility on your shoulders at
that moment I was extremely aware the
media wouldn't let us forget the
politicians would let us forget Hank
Paulson and I went to President Bush to
talk to him about the crisis in
September 08 and he basically said you
guys are in charge in you know whatever
you do I'll support you the amount of
noise was extraordinary how difficult
was it to make rational decisions it was
extraordinary it was a global financial
crisis the the news media of course
we're playing it up as they
appropriately should have inside the Fed
it was there was a cloistered feeling at
times and we were able to sit and think
and to analyze and I always tried to
focus on the immediate task the
testimony the next day the memoranda I
was working on so I did focus
concentrate on on what had to be done
nothing quite as severe as this had
happened since the late twenties early
1930s how prepared was the fed as an
institution to deal with these events
well there had been some work done after
nine eleven which obviously disrupted
the financial system quite severely so
they had been some work contingency
planning things of that sort but nothing
really prepared the Fed or anyone really
for a crisis of the scope and in nature
that the one we saw in 2008 now one of
the things you point out is looked over
here in the UK the governor of the Bank
of England was very concerned about what
economists call moral hazard which is
the idea that if you bail banks out they
then are more likely to take risks in
the future because they know they're
going to be saved why were you less
concerned about in a sense rewarding
banks for bad behavior well it's a
perfectly legitimate concern first of
all and early on in 2007 we were trying
to balance those issues and try to
figure out
the right response was but there comes a
time when the situation is sufficiently
severe that you have to respond in order
to punish you know some individuals on
Wall Street you don't want to bring down
the entire economy and what we tried to
do when we could was to make sure that
the companies that were being helped did
not benefit any more than absolutely
necessary pulling together all your
experience in the last few years do you
think politicians and indeed people
expected rather too much of central
banks and should have expected rather
more of governments yes I think that way
too much of the burden has been placed
on central banks and it's ironic people
complain about they don't like
quantitative easing they don't like low
interest rates well the central banks
are trying to use the tools they have to
accomplish their objectives if you had a
more balanced monetary fiscal mix for
example I'm talking about the United
States as well as is Europe in the UK
then central banks could do less and
some of those concerns would be less
less salient have the politicians
learned those lessons no I think
politicians have been too focused on
near-term budget cuts in all these major
countries I shall have got one slightly
more trivial question is you became a
sort of brand for the world you know the
the on YouTube all over the internet was
this idea of urban Hank not the bernanke
as it happens but the bank saving the
world how did that feel well i don't
think the burn egg was actually a very
favorable thing i mean i was obviously a
big part of on both you know those who
favored what we were doing and those who
opposed it i was a symbol of that and
it's not always very comfortable but it
comes with the job that man i keep many
thanks thank you
